data.title: Tasks Runner waits for external tool (GIT Extension) to be closed after launching it
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9
- OS Version: win7x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Configure new task:
{
    "taskName": "Open GIT Extesion",
    "suppressTaskName": true,
    "isShellCommand": true,
    "command":"gitex"
}
2. VS Code Task runner waits for GIT Extension to be closed and then shows that task was complete

Why it is the problem? Because when I launch it from terminal, command is done immediately and there is no waiting, so why task runner is waiting?

Updated:
When I execute another task, it asks to terminate running task and when I press terminate button it throws error: "The launched process doesn't exist anymore. If the task spawned background tasks exiting VS Code might result in orphaned processes."

data.title: Simplify snippet translation
data.body:
The only way to nls the following snippet string in package.json:
```json
"address": "${2:TCP/IP address of process to be debugged}"
```
is by using this in package.json:
```json
"address": "%address.description%"
```
and this in the package.nls.json:
```json
"address.description": "${2:TCP/IP address of process to be debugged}"
```
With this the translators have to deal with the snippet syntax which is error prone.

I suggest that we support something like this:
```json
"address": "${2:%address.description%}"
```
and this in the package.nls.json:
```json
"address.description": "TCP/IP address of process to be debugged"
```

data.title: Try to position editor mouseover hint boxes so they never overlay current caret position region

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
This is related to #14840 but more of an enhancement suggestion on how to solve the issue without disabling hints completely.

This is something that can become a real annoyance at times, especially if the hint boxes become large, (in TypeScript, this happens frequently due to complex types).

Let's say I'm currently editing a source file:

![clipboard01](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8589488/22590272/0b22839c-ea17-11e6-9b99-b5fef37fcb80.png)

Now I unintentionally moved the mouse cursor to hover over `options`, which has a complex interface type. When the cursor is positioned above it, a hint is shown:

![clipboard02](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8589488/22590358/7ae6341c-ea17-11e6-854c-60d6f5608dd7.png)

Unfortunately the hint is large and is positioned over the area I'm currently editing. Usually I'm concentrated on editing and don't really realize why that happened so I just press the `Esc` key to get rid of it. However, even if I do that, but then I move the cursor again just a bit (sometimes unintentionally), the hint returns, and that becomes annoying at times.

My suggestion is to always position the hint box so it doesn't overlay some rectangle within the cursor's area. The logic is quite simple, in essence:

* If the caret is above the cursor, open the hint to the bottom.
* If the caret is below, open the hint to the top.
* If the caret is to the left, open the hint to the right.
* If the caret is to the right, open the hint to the left.

Of course this only matters if the caret is anywhere close to the cursor and the hint box is large enough to reach it, and there can be many potential adjustments and tweaks for various cases. I'm just giving this as an example.

data.title: html auto-formatting: preserve my line breaks between attributes
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.0

The new `html.format.wrapAttributes` settings is nice, but can it be extended with an option to keep "manual" wrapping? 
`"html.format.wrapAttributes": "auto"` condenses all attributes into one line (or multiple lines if max length is reached).
`"html.format.wrapAttributes": "force|force-align|force-expand-multiline"` inserts a line break between each attribute.
It would be nice to have an option of making your own line breaks between attributes where you feel it's best (but so that auto-formatter still indents, removes empty lines and extra spaces, inserts missing spaces, etc.).

data.title: Autofix doesn't handle cursor/selection correctly
data.body:
_From @rebornix on October 25, 2016 17:22_

Testing https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14319 .

Repro steps:
1. Turn on eslint rule `curly` as `warn`.
2. Insert following code into the editor, put cursor just after the semicolon.
   
   ```
   if (foo) foo++;
   ```
3. Save
### Expected

The content is changed to `if (foo) {foo++;}` and the cursor is after `}`
### Actual

The content is fixed correctly while both `;` and `}` are selected.

![screen shot 2016-10-25 at 10 21 38 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/876920/19696635/d9175f0e-9a9c-11e6-83fe-aa82837136d8.png)
### Note

This issue won't happen if you already put cursor elsewhere.


_Copied from original issue: Microsoft/vscode-eslint#161_

data.title: Window scrolls while selecting text, causing selection to jump
data.body:
I've never seen this before so I suspect this is regression in 1.9.0.

- VSCode Version: 1.9.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro

I'm editing a markdown file that contains both text and code blocks. I have the preview open on the right (split screen). When I drag my mouse to highlight text in the editor on the left, it randomly scrolls, causing my selection to go the opposite way to where I was dragging from the start point.

It's really random; it took me 10-15 drags to repro for this GIF, however it seemed to be happening more frequently when I wasn't trying to repro.

I don't know how well this GIF will illustrate the issue, but I start dragging from line 217 (`items.sort();`) and drag upwards. After my selection gest to line 211, the editor suddenly scrolls down, (across a few frames of this GIF) resulting in my selection running from line 217 to 227 (the opposite direction).

![Selection scrolling](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1078012/22588681/cafe464c-e9fe-11e6-9ead-5e57e4a70a1b.gif)

data.title: Request for Ctrl+D (find next): if no text is selected, find next whole word; if selected, match all occurrences instead (like in Sublime)

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

data.body:
In Sublime Text, if you have nothing selected when you press Ctrl+D, it first selects the word where your cursor is at (VSCode also does this). Then, the next Ctrl+D will automatically use whole word search, regardless of the whole word setting.

If you have this:

```
wordword
word code word
```

And begin Ctrl+D'ing on the first standalone "word" in the second line, you will get:

```
wordword
[word] code [word]
```

(selections marked with [])

In contrast, if you already have text selected (with your mouse, or Shift+Arrow combinations), Ctrl+D will search WITHOUT whole word (i.e. matching all occurrences of the selected text even if they are not a complete token)

If select the first "word" in "wordword" with your mouse, you will get:

```
[word][word]
[word] code [word]
```

I hope my explanation was clear. :)

I understand that this might be something some users wouldn't want by default, but at least an option would be incredible, because this subtlety in Sublime avoids constantly changing whole word modes (case is respected either way) and I find it very productive.

data.title: [Feature Request] Make it easy to create file or folder in the root directory
data.body:
- VSCode Version:

```
Version 1.9.0
Commit 27240e71ef390bf2d66307e677c2a333cebf75af
Date 2017-02-02T08:31:00.827Z
Shell 1.4.6
Renderer 53.0.2785.143
Node 6.5.0
```

- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro x64

It's easy to create a file or folder in a folder with a right-click:

![vs1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7011819/22587680/d572815c-e9e9-11e6-95ba-1a1b6ca97ff9.png)

Unfortunately, that don't work for the root directory: there's no right-click menu. There are buttons to create a file or folder, which I'd expect to create in the root, but actually create in the selected directory:

![vs2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7011819/22587757/2b65a576-e9ea-11e6-925c-67521f4867d6.png)

I think allowing the right-click menu in the root would be the best option.

data.title: Questionable use of QuickPick as a confirmation dialog or alert
data.body:
When opening old projects with the VS Code 1.9.0 I now get this QuickOpen menu:

![2017-02-03_10-32-15](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1898161/22586552/b041a52a-e9fd-11e6-9949-e0b2576850cb.png)

I fully understand why we do this, but I think the use of QuickPick in this situation is confusing (and I even have proof for this from user studies done by @stevencl in debug land).

The problem with QuickPick is that it is normally used when the user explicitly triggered an action with multiple choices: the QuickPick menu does not come as a surprise in these cases.

But in the situation at hand the user has requested VS Code to open a specific workspace and does not expect a QuickPick to appear. And from past experience he has learned, that there is no QuickPick when opening a workspace.

Even I am still surprised by the QuickPick in this case and quickly press Esc to make it go away because I suspect that I've accidentally triggered some action. 

We have seen the same in the debug user studies: when users started debugging for the first time by pressing F5 they have no launch.json and a QuickPick menu appears offering different debug environment choices. Since users are not expecting this, they dismiss the menu quickly and debugging will fail. They are not realising that an important decision needs to be made here.

Could we try to introduce a different UI for situations like this? Something like an modal "alert/confirmation style" QuickPick?

/cc @stevencl @bpasero

2. open folder in vscode.
3. Make changes to the file.
4. Press Ctrl+Shift+G and click on the file to see the diff.

data.title: Support more than one running tasks
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.9.0 (27240e71ef390bf2d66307e677c2a333cebf75af, 2017-02-02T08:31:00.827Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.1.7601
---
Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a asp.net core app
2. Setup launch to start app
3. Use preLaunchTask to build dotnet app
4. Setup tasks
5. Create task to build dotnet (preLaunchTask)
6. Create second task to start tsc in watch mode
7. Run tsc - Task
8. Press F5 to launch dotnet app.

As you can see, you get an error that a task is already running and the preLaunchTask cannot be started.

It should be possible to run more than one tasks at a time. For every running task show a seperated terminal.

A example programm  you can find [here](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/750027/Test.zip)

data.title: How to find all references / peek definition / go to definition work across whole project ?
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9.0
- OS Version: 10.12.2

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a project by dragging its outermost folder on the visual studio code icon
2. Try to "Find all references" or "Go to definition" or just using a function defined in another file.

Expectation: 
it would search across all files. Or give intellisense from that function defined in that other file.

Current Behaviour: 
only references in currently opened file are shown.
definition is not found if it’s not in the same folder.
no intellisense is provided if the function is not in the same file.

My code is pure javascript (es6), html & scss
Folder structure:
```
.git/
.vscode/
build/
api/
debian/
doc/
node_modules/
scripts/
src/ <--- main folder I’m working with
target/
.gitignore
package.json
README.md
```

Thanks for your help

data.title: `showOutput` setting is not respected anymore if a build task is programmatically started when an extension is activated (appeared in 1.9)
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install the [Blade Runner](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=yukidoi.blade-runner) extension (an extension that starts a build task whenever a workspace is opened).
2. Set up a build task for the workspace.
3. Make sure `showOutput` is set to `never` in `tasks.json`.
4. Open the workspace.

In 1.8 everything worked as expected, the `output` panel didn't show up when `showOutput` was set to `never` or `silent` (and the task had a matcher). In 1.9 this doesn't seem to work anymore. So the output panel now pops up every time the project is opened (which is a bit annoying).

The source code used by the extension is:

```ts
import * as vscode from 'vscode'; 

export function activate(context: vscode.ExtensionContext) {
	vscode.commands.executeCommand("workbench.action.tasks.build");
}
```

Is there a change in the API that needs to be addressed? or is this a bug?

data.title: Block cursor is not rendered properly (visual glitches)
data.body:
After updating VSCode I noticed that my cursor (block) was not behaving correctly.

While examining the behaviour I noticed the following:
1. All problem disappear when changing back to regular cursor
2. The weird cursor placement (out of bounds) depends on my current font (Operator Mono Light)
3. The block cursor tab highlighting that follows inappropriately is unaffected by font change

- VSCode Version: 1.9.0
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.3

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Set `"editor.cursorStyle": "block"` (and change font to e.g. `OperatorMono-Light`)
2. Move or click around with cursor
